Resolved Question Show me another » Help With Precalculus Worksheet? 2. Solve the following: a) A small fast – food restaurant invest $5000 to produce a new food item that will sell for $3.49. Each iterm can be produced for $2.16. i) How many items must be sold to break even ? ii) How many items must be sold to make a profit of $8500? b) You are offered two jobs selling dental supplies. One company offers a straight commission of 6% of sales. The other company offers a salary of $350 per week plus 3% of sales. How much would you have to sell in a week in order to make the straight commission offer better? c) At a local high school city championship basketball game, 1435 tickets were sold. A student admission ticket cost $1.50 and an adult admission ticket cost $5.00. The total ticket receipts for the basketball game were $3552.50. How many of each type of ticket were sold? d) A small corporation borrowed $775,000 to expand its clothing line. Some of the money was borrowed at 8%, some at 9%, and some at 10%. How much was borrowed at each rate if the annual interest owed was $67,500 and the amount borrowed at 8% was four times the amount borrowed at 10%
6. a) A triangular brick wall is made by cutting some bricks in half to use in the first column of every row. The wall has 28 rows. The top row is one – half brick wide and the bottom row is 14 bricks wide. How many bricks are used in the finished wall? b) Determine the seating capacity of an auditorium with 36 rows of seats if there are 15 seats in the first row, 18 seats in the second row, 21 seats in the third row, and so on.
c) An object with negligible air resistance is dropped from the top of the Petronas Toweers in Malaysia at a height of 1483 feet. During the first second of the fall, the object falls 4.9 feet, during the second second, it falls 14.7 feet, during the third second, it falls 34.3 feet. If this arithmetic pattern continues, how many feet will the object fall in 17 seconds?
9. a) A tool and die company buys a machine for $135,000 and it depreciates at a rate of 30% per year. (In other words, at the end of each year the depreciated value is 70% of what it was at the beginning of the year.) Find the depreciated value of the machine after 5 full years. b) A rubber ball is dropped from a height of 60 feet. If it rebounds approximately two – thirds the distance after each fall, use an infinite geometric series to approximate the total distance the ball travels. 2 years ago Report Abuse by Ingeniou... Best Answer - Chosen by Asker wrong section for this - business finance (accounting to be precise)
2 a) i) b/e = fc/(sp-vc) = 5000/(3.49-2.16) = 5000/1.33 = 3759.40 i.e. 3760 items ii) b/e + fixed profit = (fc + profit)/(sp-vc) = (5000+8500)/(3.49-2.16) = 13500/1.33 = 10150.38 i.e. 10151 items
b) let x = quantity sold 350 + 0.03x = 0.06x 350 = 0.03x; x = $11666.67
c) 3552.50 = 1.5s + 5a s +a = 1435
using the substitution method, s = 1435 - a 3552.50 = 1.5(1435-a) +5a 3552.50 = 2152.50 - 1.5a + 5a 3552.50 = 2152.50 + 3.5a 1400 = 3.5a; a = 400 adult tickets s = 1435 -a s = 1435 - 400 = 1035 student tickets
d) 0.08x + 0.09y + 0.10z = 67500 x+y+z = 775000 4z = x
0.08*4z + 0.09y + 0.10z = 67500 0.42z + 0.09y = 67500
z + y + 4z = 775000 5z + y = 775000 y = 775000 - 5z
0.42z + 0.09(775000 -5z) = 67500 0.42z + 69750 - 0.45z = 67500 -0.03z + 69750 = 67500 -0.03z = -2250; z = 75000 as 4z = x; x = 300000 y = 775000 - 5z = 775000 - 5*75000 = 400000
6) a) trapezium = (1/2)(a+b)h = (1/2)*(14+0.5)*28 = 14*14.5 = 203 bricks b) tn = 12 + 3n; at row = 36; tn = 12 + 36*3 = 12 + 108 = 120 trapezium = (1/2)(15+120)*36 = 18*135 = 2430 seats c) s = a + b(t -1); s = additional distance, a = 4.9, b = 9.8, t = time s = 4.9 + 9.8*(17-1) = 4.9 + 156.8 = 161.7 ft total distance fell using trapezium rule: (1/2)(4.9+161.7)*17 = 83.3*17 = 1416.1ft
9) a) presuming we are using a reducing balance (i.e. the depreciation is compounded and is not straight line), $135000*0.7^5 = 135000*0.16807 = $22689.45 remaining b) requires a bit of thinking on this one... if the ball falls 60ft, it rebounds (2/3) of this distance back up but falls the same distance on the way down. on the second time it rebounds (2/3) of the prior distance back up but falls the same distance back down and so on. You are looking at 2 of the same distance travelled everytime the ball rebounds after the first drop ball rebounds at a*2/3, so distance = a(2/3)^(n-1); geometric sum = a/(1- 2/3) = 60/(1/3) = 180 however the fall of the ball needs to be considered. This is at the rate ar^(n-2) where a = 40; geometric sum = 40/(1/3) = 120 total distance travelled is 180 for the rebounds and 120 for the falls which gives a total of 300ft
